message_1: A rectangular container with dimensions 10 cm x 15 cm x 20 cm is filled to the brim with water. Determine the hydrostatic pressure at the bottom of the container and the buoyant force acting on the container if it is completely submerged in water. (Take the density of water to be 1000 kg/m³ and g to be 9.81 m/s²)
message_2:
First, let's convert the dimensions of the container to meters: 0.1 m x 0.15 m x 0.2 m.

1. Hydrostatic pressure at the bottom of the container:

The hydrostatic pressure (P) at the bottom of the container can be calculated using the formula:

P = ρ * g * h

where ρ is the density of water (1000 kg/m³), g is the acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m/s²), and h is the height of the water column (0.2 m).

P = 1000 kg/m³ * 9.81 m/s² * 0.2 m
P = 1962 Pa (Pascals)

So, the hydrostatic pressure at the bottom of the container is 1962 Pa.

2. Buoyant force acting on the container:

The buoyant force (F_b) can be calculated using the formula:

F_b = ρ * V * g

where ρ is the density of water (1000 kg/m³), V is the volume of the container, and g is the acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m/s²).

First, let's calculate the volume of the container:

V = length * width * height
V = 0.1 m * 0.15 m * 0.2 m
V = 0.003 m³

Now, we can calculate the buoyant force:

F_b = 1000 kg/m³ * 0.003 m³ * 9.81 m/s²
F_b = 29.43 N (Newtons)

So, the buoyant force acting on the container when it is completely submerged in water is 29.43 N.
